org.activebpel.rt.bpel.xpath.ast.visitors
Class AeXPathSerializeNodeVisitor

java.lang.Object
  org.activebpel.rt.bpel.xpath.ast.visitors.AeAbstractXPathNodeVisitor
      org.activebpel.rt.bpel.xpath.ast.visitors.AeAbstractTraversingXPathNodeVisitor
          org.activebpel.rt.bpel.xpath.ast.visitors.AeXPathSerializeNodeVisitor
All Implemented Interfaces:
IAeXPathNodeVisitor
public class AeXPathSerializeNodeVisitor
extends AeAbstractTraversingXPathNodeVisitor

This class is used to serialize an XPath AST into a string representation of the XPath. It is not guaranteed that the resulting serialized XPath will be identical to the one that created the AST, but it should be functionally equivalent.

visitPathExpression

protected void visitPathExpression(AeAbstractXPathNode aNode)
Common visit for nodes that are effectively just paths. This means that all of the children of the node are simply concat'd using '/' as the separator.

Parameters:
aNode -

visitBooleanNode

protected void visitBooleanNode(AeAbstractXPathBooleanNode aNode,
                                java.lang.String aSeparator)
Common visit for all boolean nodes. This method is needed because the tree will look a little weird for the following xpath: /path/to/data[@attr1 = 'value1' and @attr2 = 'value2'] In the above instance, the predicate node will have a single child node of type 'and'. That 'and' child will have three children: a relative path, an equality expression, and another and expression.

Parameters:
aNode -
aSeparator -

visitMultiArgBooleanNode

protected void visitMultiArgBooleanNode(AeAbstractXPathBooleanNode aNode,
                                        java.lang.String aSeparator)
Called to visit a boolean node that has more than 2 children. See documenation for visitBooleanNode for details.

Parameters:
aNode -

visitNodeWithSeparator

protected void visitNodeWithSeparator(AeAbstractXPathNode aNode,
                                      java.lang.String aSeparator)
Appends/visits all of the node's children using the given separator to separate them.
